TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit HashPartitionResolver extends System.Object implements class Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.IPartitionResolver, class System.IDisposable
Public Class HashPartitionResolver Implements IDisposable, IPartitionResolver
type HashPartitionResolver = class interface IPartitionResolver interface IDisposable

Attribute.AttributeName: [System.Obsolete("Support for IPartitionResolver based classes is now obsolete. It's recommended that you use partitioned collections for higher storage and throughput.")]
[<System.Obsolete("Support for IPartitionResolver based classes is now obsolete. It's recommended that you use partitioned collections for higher storage and throughput.")>]

Docs.summary: HashPartitionResolver implements partitioning based on the value of a hash function, allowing you to evenly distribute requests and data across a number of partitions in the Azure Cosmos DB service.

remarks.para: Support for IPartitionResolver based classes is now obsolete. It's recommended that you use Partitioned Collections for higher storage and throughput.

The HashPartitionResolver class internally implements a consistent hash ring over the hash function specified in the interface. By default, the HashPartitionResolver provides an MD5 hash function, but this can be swapped out with a different hashing implementation. The consistent hash ring creates 16 replicas for each collection in order to achieve a more uniform distribution of documents across collections.

The hash partitioning is most suitable for partitioning when the partition key has a high cardinality because it will distribute the data evenly across collections. Typically hash partitioning uses the id property. A common use cases for hash partitioning is data produced or consumed from a large number of distinct clients or for storing user profiles, catalog items, and telemetry data.

Docs.remarks: Use when you want to partition based on a single property name. For other partitioning schemes, use the constructor with partitionKeyExtractor instead.

Docs.summary: The number of virtual nodes per collection in the conisistent hash ring in the Azure Cosmos DB service. This controls the compromise of skewness of documents accross collections vs the consistent hashing latency.

Docs.summary: Gets the name of the property in the document to execute the hashing on in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
Docs.value: The name of the property in the document to execute the hashing on.
Docs.remarks: HashPartitionResolver supports two modes - one using PartitionKeyPropertyName and the other using PartitionKeyExtractor. PartitionKeyPropertyName is extracted using Reflection, so use the C# property name, not the JSON representation.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<string> ResolveForRead (object partitionKey);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<string> ResolveForRead(object partitionKey) cil managed
Public Overridable Function ResolveForRead (partitionKey As Object) As IEnumerable(Of String)
abstract member ResolveForRead : obj -> seq<string> override this.ResolveForRead : obj -> seq<string>

Docs.param: The partition key used to determine the target collections for reading. Must be a string.
Docs.summary: Given a partition key, returns a list of collection links to read from using its hash in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
Docs.returns: The list of target collection links.
Docs.remarks: If partitionKey is null, then all collections are returned. The HashPartitionResolver supports only strings as partitionKeys. For other types, use ToString() or JsonConvert.SerializeObject() to convert to string.
Docs.exception: Thrown if the partition key is not a string.
